The Terrorism section of the Guinea-Bissau page warns that attacks cannot be ruled out, including at beach resorts, hotels, cafés and restaurants. It highlights a high threat of terrorist attack globally affecting UK interests and British nationals. It also provides links to advice on staying safe abroad and reducing the risk from terrorism while abroad.

The "Local Laws and Customs" section for Guinea-Bissau advises against involvement with drugs due to severe penalties and harsh prison conditions. It recommends carrying identification at all times. The page also contains information on tolerance for homosexuality if discreet and provides a link to advice for the LGBT community.

The Entry Requirements page for Guinea-Bissau covers a variety of information. Topics include the current travel rules for British citizens, COVID-19 entry procedures and regulations for both vaccinated and non-vaccinated travellers, eligibility criteria for those who have had COVID-19 in the past year, rules for children, transit instructions, and details about visas, yellow fever certificates, and passport validity.

The Health section of the Guinea-Bissau page provides information on how to prepare your health before travelling, like checking if your destination can provide the adequate healthcare you may need and ensuring that you have appropriate travel insurance. It also gives several pieces of related advice, covering essential details on vaccines, health risks, medical treatment, and mental health considerations before and during your trip. Moreover, it alerts about significant health risks in the country, such as Zika virus transmission, Malaria, Dengue fever, and HIV/AIDS.
The Money section of the Guinea-Bissau page provides information about the local currency, the predominantly cash-based economy, the rare use of credit cards, and the scarcity of ATMs.

The 'Travel advice help and support' section for Guinea-Bissau provides emergency contact information for the UK government while abroad. It also includes a foreign travel checklist, travel safety tips, advice on refunds & cancellations, and information on registering travel details. It features links to previous versions of FCDO travel advice and offers further assistance via Twitter, Facebook, or direct enquiry.
Latest FCDO travel advice for Lesotho including on entry requirements, safety and security and local laws and customs.

The Summary section for Lesotho highlights important travel and entry requirements due to COVID-19, the significance of travel insurance, consular support details for British nationals, and potential political demonstrations in Maseru. It also mentions that there's no recent history of terrorism, but attacks can't be ruled out. Most visits to the country are typically trouble-free.

The Coronavirus section for Lesotho includes the latest COVID-19 risk information, travel advice during the pandemic, and the current entry requirements. It suggests precautions for changing travel plans due to potential new COVID-19 rules. It also provides information regarding travel in Lesotho, healthcare, and financial supports accessible while abroad.

The Safety and Security section for Lesotho advises on crime risks, detailing precautions to avoid being mugged and securing valuables. It provides guidance on local and road travel, cautioning against poor driving standards and roaming animals. The section also discusses air travel safety, political situations and advises to avoid any demonstrations or unusual security force activities.

The Terrorism section for Lesotho states that despite no recent history of terrorism, potential attacks cannot be ruled out. It provides information and advice on staying safe and reducing risks from terrorism while abroad. It highlights a global high threat of terrorist attack affecting UK interests and British nationals, urging constant vigilance.

The "Local laws and customs" section for Lesotho covers information regarding: the criminalisation of consensual same-sex relations between men (not usually enforced); potential stigma towards LGBTQI people; severe punishments for drug possession; and regulations for driving, including a minimum age of 21 for renting a car.

The Entry Requirements section for Lesotho includes details about current travel rules for British citizens, noting that all COVID-19 restrictions have been lifted in the country. It provides information regarding transiting through South Africa, passport validity, visa procurement at arrival, and yellow fever certificate requirements. It also addresses specific directions for those travelling with children via a South African airport.
